author: bridge-bot
content:
<somnergy> re: **@KamilChNethermind**
> We should avoid by all costs using same libraries in all clients tbh to not introduce new type of security threats.

Optimize what we can with currently used ones and if there is a space for change (when there is good diversity) - try that.
Isn't it more likely that one person in one team re-writing a library/impl for performance gains would introduce more bugs than many teams looking at and fixing a single library?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@gas_limit_testing_bot**
> <.fjl> it's not about the bugs
it's about the journey ;)

author: sky.cactus
content: Writing the same code multiple times increases the total number of bugs (as a raw count), but *greatly* reduces the chance that bugs will slip through testing, and if such a bug does slip through testing it is very unlikely the whole network will be affected (assuming client diversity in deployment).

author: sky.cactus
content: Having lots of bugs during development isn't really a big deal.  Having *any* bugs in production is a very big deal.

author: bridge-bot
content: <somnergy> Philosophy aside, the amount of resources spent to reach quality with that diversity might outweigh the benefits at this stage, even if it sounds good on paper

author: .fjl
content: I think it's important to make sure MODEXP can be implemented without relying on a specific library. Yes, in practice many clients will use GMP. But the gas cost should not be modeled on GMP exactly, because doing so won't leave room for future implementations to do it a different way.

author: bridge-bot
content: <somnergy> I agree. For now we can take the worst case(25 Mgas or so) and we will see how/what different clients do in the future on this

author: sky.cactus
content: Performance is always a cost for building robust, resilient, censorship resistant, privacy preserving software.  If we are willing to compromise on those things, we can trivially improve performance by orders of magnitude, but we would no longer be building the same thing.
